text: Since 2011 (measurements reported in AR5), concentrations have continued to increase in the atmosphere, reaching annual averages of 410 parts per million (ppm) for carbon dioxide (CO 2), 1866 parts per billion (ppb) for methane (CH 4), and 332 ppb for nitrous oxide (N 2O) in 2019.6 Land and ocean have taken up a near-constant proportion (globally about 56% per year) of CO 2 emissions from human activities over the past six decades, with regional differences
gpt_revised_text: Concentrations of carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide in the atmosphere have continued to increase since 2011, with annual averages of 410 parts per million (ppm), 1866 parts per billion (ppb), and 332 ppb in 2019 respectively. Land and ocean have consistently absorbed about 56% of CO2 emissions from human activities globally over the past six decades, showing regional variations.

text: Mid-latitude storm tracks have likely shifted poleward in both hemispheres since the 1980s, with marked seasonality in trends
gpt_revised_text: Mid-latitude storm tracks have shifted poleward in both hemispheres since the 1980s, with marked seasonality in trends.

text: The average rate of sea level rise was 1.3 [0.6 to 2.1] mm yr–1 between 1901 and 1971, increasing to 1.9 [0.8 to 2.9] mm yr–1 between 1971 and 2006, and further increasing to 3.7 [3.2 to 4.2] mm yr–1 between 2006 and 2018
gpt_revised_text: The average rate of sea level rise was 1.3 mm yr–1 between 1901 and 1971, increasing to 1.9 mm yr–1 between 1971 and 2006, and further increasing to 3.7 mm yr–1 between 2006 and 2018, with human influence very likely being the main driver of these increases since at least 1971.

text: Since 1750, increases in CO 2 (47%) and CH 4 (156%) concentrations far exceed – and increases in N 2O (23%) are similar to – the natural multi-millennial changes between glacial and interglacial periods over at least the past 800,000 years
gpt_revised_text: Increases in CO2 by 47% and CH4 by 156% since 1750 greatly surpass historic changes between glacial and interglacial periods over the last 800,000 years, with N2O increases of 23% being similar to those natural changes.
